docs.lead_paragraph: International A2-9 A NEW VIEW OF ARAFAT In his role as head of the Palestinian Authority, Yasir Arafat is being judged by new standards, leaving many disappointed as he struggles in the transition from national symbol to public servant.ARAFAT A1 LITTLE PROGRESS IN SYRIA TALKS Little progress was made in peace talks between Israel and Syria, with many issues unresolved. But there was agreement that a demilitarized zone would be needed around the Golan Heights. A6

docs.lead_paragraph: On basically party-line votes, the House and the Senate today adopted a seven-year Republican plan that is supposed to cut taxes, limit spending for Medicare and other social programs and balance the Federal budget by the year 2002. The votes showed in stark colors how much the political landscape has changed since Republicans won control of Congress in the election last November.
docs.snippet: On basically party-line votes, the House and the Senate today adopted a seven-year Republican plan that is supposed to cut taxes, limit spending for Medicare and other social programs and balance the Federal budget by the year 2002.   The votes...

docs.lead_paragraph: As they sped toward their summer recess, state lawmakers today approved the first mandatory increase in minimum automobile insurance limits in nearly 40 years, a measure that would provide greater protections for accident victims but would drive up premiums for every driver in the state. Also today, after hours of chaotic negotiation and intense lobbying, the Republican-led Senate and the Democratic-controlled Assembly passed a resolution that could start New York down the path toward legalized casino gambling. [ Page B6 ] .

headline.main: Rise in Auto Insurance Minimums Is Voted

docs.lead_paragraph: House and Senate Adopt Budget Plan The House and Senate adopted a Republican plan that would cut taxes, limit spending for Medicare and other social programs and balance the Federal budget by 2002. The budget resolution is just a blueprint, setting levels for revenue and spending in categories like health, defense and transportation. The details of which taxes would be lowered and how spending would be restrained will not be decided until other legislation is voted on this fall. [ Page A1. ] Prices Tumble in Credit Markets Prices of Treasury securities tumbled after a report showing unexpected strength in housing dashed many traders' hopes that the Fed would push down interest rates soon. [ D16. ] Sales of new homes rose 19.9 percent during May, the fastest growth rate in nearly three and a half years. [ D16. ] Panel Approves Bank Bill The House Banking Committee approved a bill that would repeal laws intended to protect consumers, but the measure appears to have sharply diminished the odds of any banking legislation's emerging from Congress this year. The controversy stems from an amendment that would allow banks to affiliate with insurance companies, an idea previously defeated. [ D2. ] Trade Pact Raises Questions Japan and the United States may have reached a last-minute trade agreement, but in both countries the question being asked is, "Who won?" [ D5. ] An Exxon Russia Deal Expected Exxon is expected to sign an agreement in Moscow today that would take it a step closer to participating in a $15 billion project to develop oil and natural gas fields off Sakhalin Island in the Russian Far East. [ D3. ] Purchase by Morgan Stanley Morgan Stanley is paying $350 million to buy Miller Anderson & Sherrerd, a money management firm that controls about $33 billion, to stabilize its earnings flow. [ D2. ] RJR Shuffles Executive Suite RJR Nabisco said H. John Greeniaus, who heads the company's Nabisco food business, would assume oversight of sagging domestic tobacco operations, with the new title of vice chairman. [ D3. ] Endangered-Species Act Upheld The Supreme Court rejected arguments by timber and other business interests and upheld Federal rules that protect endangered species by barring the destruction of essential habitat on private land. [ A24. ] Deal for Another Submarine Senators struck a deal to build one more Seawolf submarine at the Electric Boat division of General Dynamics in Groton, Conn., raising hopes for thousands of military workers in New England. [ B4 ] . Occidental Settles Lawsuit The chemical subsidiary of Occidental Petroleum has agreed to pay $65.7 million to settle a two-year-old class-action suit in Texas regarding a chemical leak from one of its plants in 1992. [ D20. ] New York Stars for Nathan's A new campaign for Nathan's Famous hot dogs makes the most out of the company's small ad budget with a commercial that turns boxer shorts, jack-hammers, cabdrivers and Nathan's hot dogs into a paean to New York. [ D4. ] Some Optimism for Biotech The biotechnology industry has resurged a bit this year as the stocks of several companies strongly recovered. Market Place. [ D6. ]

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re your June 26 front-page news analysis on changes in the health care system as a byproduct of budget cutting: The important point you make is that while the proposed slowdown in Medicare and Medicaid spending, which accounts for almost one-third of total health care spending in this country, will probably have a major impact on our health care system, nobody is sure yet just how that impact will play out.

headline.main: Even Before Medicare Cuts, Health Care System Has Changed

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman came to Holy Name Hospital today to sign a bill requiring insurers to pay for a second day of hospital care for mothers and their newborns, making the state the second in the nation to regulate what critics have called "drive-through deliveries." It was the latest result of the growing public backlash against the decision by health maintenance organizations to cover only 24 hours of hospital care after normal births. A decade ago, most women and their infants remained in a hospital for three or four days for rest, observation and tests.

headline.main: New Mothers Gain 2d Day In Hospital

docs.lead_paragraph: The rough new politics of Medicaid erupted before the Senate Finance Committee today as a panel of governors debated Republican proposals to cut $180 billion over seven years from the health insurance program for the poor and the disabled. Democratic governors contended that the cuts could be devastating and far exceeded what could be achieved through greater use of managed care or giving the states greater administrative flexibility, as the Republicans have promised. Republican governors were generally more supportive.

headline.main: Congressional Roundup: Congress and White House Make Last Effort to Compromise on '95 Budget; Medicaid Politics Get Rough
